Key Match Events: Shota Imanaga gave up two runs in the first but allowed three runs on four hits while striking out eight and walking just one in six innings.
Pete Crow-Armstrong hit a two-RBI double that put the Cubs up a run in the second inning.
Cody Bellinger hit a two-run shot, giving the Cubs all the runs they'd score on the night.
Nate Pearson faced the minimum in two scoreless frames, giving up one hit and striking out two.
Tyson Miller faced four batters from the left side and allowed three of them to reach in the ninth.
Drew Smyly walked CJ Abrams, struck out Keibert Ruiz, and allowed a two-RBI single to Jacob Young.
Keegan Thompson struck out Dylan Crews to end the game with a curveball.
Porter Hodge was down after throwing 36 pitches Wednesday.
Pre-Game Insights: Manager Craig Counsell emphasized the importance of strong bullpen performance.
The Cubs are known for their September runs.
Post-Match Reflections: Cubs ace Shota Imanaga was a little rusty at first but managed to give up just three earned runs in six innings.
Cubs' short bullpen pushed through the game, with key performances from Nate Pearson and Keegan Thompson.
The Cubs' offense stalled after a seven-run second inning.
Cubs' manager Craig Counsell expressed satisfaction with the team's performance despite the close win.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The @Cubs put up SEVEN in the 2nd
Dylan Crews, a top prospect, homered Wednesday and again earlier in the night against Imanaga.
Shawn Armstrong was picked up by the Cubs from the St. Louis Cardinals.
